item.title: Diagonalization and Powers of a Matrix
item.description: 19.1 Diagonalization of a Matrix Suppose for a given matrix $A$, we have $n$ linearlly independent eigenvectros and we put them in a matrix $S$. Then $AS = A \begin{bmatrix} x_1 & x_2 & … & x_n \end{bmatrix}$, where each $x_i$ is the eigenvector. But for each of the eigenvectors, $Ax_i = \lambda_ix_i$. Hence, $AS = A \begin{bmatrix} x_1 & x_2 & … & x_n \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1x_1 & \lambda_2x_2 & … & \lambda_nx_n \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 & x_2 & … & x_n \end{bmatrix}diag(\lambda_i) = S\Lambda$.
